chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess suspected osteoarthritis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If osteoarthritis is suspected and alternative conditions have been excluded, assess the person to guide appropriate management.

  • Ask about:
    • The location, onset, duration, progression, pattern, and severity of symptoms, such as pain and stiffness.
    • Any risk factors for osteoarthritis.
    • Any history of trauma or systemic symptoms, which may indicate an alternative diagnosis.
    • Hand dominance (if relevant) and any functional impairment, including effect on daily activities such as walking, exercise, sleep quality, work, and participation in leisure or sport.
    • The psychosocial impact, including the person's quality of life, effect on mood and relationships, housing situation, and any dependents affected. See the CKS topics on Generalized anxiety disorder and Depression for more information.
    • Any self-help strategies and treatments tried, including over-the-counter medication.
    • Any family history of osteoarthritis or joint problems.
    • Any co-morbidities, such as chronic pain syndrome, obesity, falls risk.
    • Social support available, such as family and/or carer(s), any adjustments to home or workplace needed.
  • Examine the person to assess:
    • For typical clinical features of osteoarthritis of the affected joint(s), posture and gait (if relevant).
      • Note: if there is suspected knee involvement, exclude referred pain from the hip, which may be suggested by groin tenderness and pain on internal rotation of the hip.
    • For associated sources of pain, such as peri-articular pain, trigger finger, ganglion, bursitis, or pseudogout (pyrophosphate arthropathy) which may coexist with osteoarthritis.
    • Body weight and body mass index (BMI). See the CKS topic on Obesity for more information.
  • Routine X-ray of the affected joint(s) is not usually needed to confirm the diagnosis. Consider arranging an X-ray, depending on clinical judgement:
    • If there is diagnostic uncertainty.
    • To exclude alternative conditions.
    • If there is a sudden clinical deterioration in symptoms.
      • Typical radiological features of osteoarthritis include subchondral bone thickening and/or cysts; osteophyte formation (new bone formation at joint margins); loss or narrowing of the joint space (provides an estimate of the severity of cartilage damage).
    • Note: structural changes on X-ray may not correlate with reported symptoms and functional impairment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the assessment of suspected osteoarthritis are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Osteoarthritis: care and management [NICE, 2014], the European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) expert consensus documents EULAR recommendations for the use of imaging in the clinical management of peripheral joint osteoarthritis [Sakellariou, 2017] and EULAR recommendations for the health professional's approach to pain management in inflammatory arthritis and osteoarthritis [Geenen, 2018], and expert opinion in review articles on osteoarthritis [Glyn-Jones, 2015], on hip osteoarthritis [Aresti, 2016], and on thumb pain [Dickson et al, 2015].

  • The NICE guideline and EULAR expert consensus document note that multiple factors influence a person's experience of pain, including health beliefs, mood, avoidance behaviour, obesity, sleep disturbance, and the pattern of rest and activity through the day [NICE, 2014; Geenen, 2018]. In addition, chronic pain at one site can influence the experience of pain elsewhere in the body [NICE, 2014]. These documents support a holistic assessment of a person's physical, social, and psychological needs, in order to provide an individualised management approach which encourages positive health-seeking behaviours.
  • The recommendations on when to consider arranging a joint X-ray is largely based on the NICE guideline, which highlights that X-ray investigation is not normally needed in people with typical clinical features of osteoarthritis [NICE, 2014]. This is supported by the EULAR expert consensus document on imaging, which included a systematic literature review of the knee, hip, hand, and foot joints. It noted that imaging features do not predict the response to non-surgical treatment or prognosis [Sakellariou, 2017]. This approach is also supported by expert opinion in a review article [Dickson et al, 2015].
  • The information on the radiological features of osteoarthritis is based on the NICE guideline [NICE, 2014] and expert opinion in review articles [Glyn-Jones, 2015; Aresti, 2016].
  • The information that there may not be a correlation between structural changes on X-ray and a person's symptoms and functional impairment is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2014] and expert opinion in review articles [Glyn-Jones, 2015; Aresti, 2016].
